Type of MoS2 Specific surface area (m2/g) Pore volume (cm3/g) BJH pore size (nm) Leaf-shaped MoS2 37.8 0.216 2–4 and 5–25 Flower-shaped MoS2 18.9 0.140 2–5 and >15 Photo-catalytic degradation of methyl orange under visible light by MoS2 nanosheets produced by H2SiO3 exfoliation Wenhong Liu a Qingzhuo Hu b Fei Mo b Jiajia Hu b Yi Feng b ⁎ Huawei Tang a Haonan Ye a Shiding Miao a ⁎⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology (HFUT), Tunxi Road 193, 230009, Hefei, PR China School of Chemical Engineering, Hefei University of Technology (HFUT) Tunxi Road 193 Hefei 230009 PR China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, HFUT, Tunxi Road 193, 230009, Hefei, PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering, HFUT Tunxi Road 193 Hefei 230009 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract MoS2 nanosheets were for the first time prepared by H2SiO3 exfoliation, i.e., the precursors ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and thiourea) were embedded inside the hydrogel of H2SiO3 which provides steric hindrance for MoS2 growth. After removal of H2SiO3, MoS2 nanosheets were obtained. The appropriate dosage of hydrogel of silicic acid is the determining factor in preparing homogeneous nanosheets of MoS2. The prepared MoS2 nanosheets possess a high specific surface area of 37.8m2/g, and present excellent UV–visible-NIR absorbance properties, and the absorption peaks of visible region are much higher than that of ultraviolet region. Therefore, they can be used as excellent catalysts for visible-light-driven degradation of methyl orange (MO). The effect of photo-degradation parameters of MO including pH value, dosage of catalyst and initial concentration was studied. The strongly acidic solution of MO facilitates producing free radicals of OH in this catalytic system. The MoS2 nanosheets can be reused 10 times with little change of degradation rate, indicating that they are stable under visible-light irradiation. Keywords MoS2 nanosheets H2SiO3 exfoliation Photo-catalytic degradation Methyl orange Visible light irradiation 1 Introduction Dyes wastewater has been destroying the ecological environment as a result of industrial effluents. Among dye pollutants, the dye with the aromatic structure such as methyl orange (MO) and Victoria Blue R is a kind of stable azo compounds with biological toxicity [1,2]. Dealing with the pollutants demands the development of clean and effective decontamination technologies. Photo-catalytic degradation under visible light is one of the most promising methods [3–5]; and the crux of this technology is to find a low-cost and high efficiency photo-catalyst [6]. Fe(III)-salen complex can be used as a good photo-catalyst of organic dyes degradation under visible light; but hydrogen peroxide used for the oxidants increases the cost of degradation [7]. Oxygen in air is beyond doubt the best oxidants for photo-catalytic degradation. However; according to our knowledge; no prior work regarding the application of pure exfoliated sheets of MoS2 in photo-catalytic degradation by oxygen under visible light has been reported to date. As an important semiconductor material, the exfoliated sheets of MoS2 have recently generated attention because of its promising applications in many areas, such as H2 production, [8–10] batteries, [11–13] photoluminescence [14] and transistors [15]. MoS2 is a typical lamellar compound, which is similar to graphene. The unit cell of it consists of three atom layers where molybdenum atoms are sandwiched between layers of sulfur atoms. Because of the weak van der Waals interactions between the sheets of sulfide atoms, MoS2 can be exfoliated into thin layers, resulting in brilliant catalytic and optical adjustability [16]. Currently, many methods were used to prepare MoS2 exfoliated sheets, but the most effective and promising technology is the exfoliation of MoS2, such as scotch tape assisted micromechanical exfoliation [17,18], solution exfoliation [19,20] and intercalation assisted exfoliation [14,21,22]. However, the first two are low production efficiency, and the last is laborious and high-cost. Hence, it is desirable to develop a simple, low-cost but efficient strategy to produce exfoliated sheets of MoS2 on a large scale in order to realize their practical applications. In this study, we prepared MoS2 nanosheets by H2SiO3 exfoliation. The precursors ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and thiourea) were embedded inside hydrogel of active silicic acid which provides steric hindrance for the MoS2 growth. After removal of H2SiO3, the exfoliated nanosheets of MoS2 were obtained. The appropriate dosage of hydrogel of silicic acid is the determining factor in preparing homogeneous nanosheets of MoS2. The exfoliated sheets of MoS2 possess excellent visible light absorbance properties, and it can be used as a high efficient visible-light-driven catalyst for degradation of MO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MoS2 exfoliated sheets Typically, 2.00g (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and desired amount of tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) were loaded in round-bottom flask in which certain volume of hydrochloric acid (1mol/L) solution was added to maintain pH value at 1.0–2.0. After homogenization thiourea (1.50g, 0.0197mol) was added to the solution. The mixture was loaded in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After sealing, the mixture was maintained at a step-wise temperature treatment, i.e., 85°C for 20min and 200°C for 5h. The resultant products were collected, washed and re-dispersed in a 1.5mol/L NaOH solution (200ml) to etch silica. After filtration, the final products were washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol three times. The products were dried at 80°C to get a granular sample. In control experiments, according to the dosage of TEOS, the products yielded from different SiO2/MoS2 molar ratios of 2.5 and 0.8 TEOS are named as Leaf-shaped MoS2 and Flower-shaped MoS2 respectively. 2.2 Characterizations The micro-structure of the as-prepared MoS2 was studied by a high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100F type, JEOL). Micro-Raman measurements of the samples were carried out by using a spectrometer (LABRAM-HR, JY) excited by an incident laser (λ=532nm). Low-temperature N2 adsorption was performed on a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020M system at −196°C. Samples were degassed under flowing argon at 300°C for 5h before nitrogen adsorption, the specific area was estimated by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the pore-size distribution was obtained from the desorption isotherms following the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) mode. The diffuse reflection spectrum was tested using UV–visible-NIR spectrophotometer (DUV-3700). 2.3 Evaluation of photo-degradation In a typical experiment, the desired amount of MoS2 sheets and 200ml MO solution were loaded in 500ml beaker. After keeping ultrasonic concussion for 15min, the photo-catalytic degradation of MO was carried out using a 300W incandescent lamp at 25°C under continuous stiring, and the light source was located 15cm above dye solution. After irradiation, the suspension was centrifuged, and the concentration of MO solution was determined using UV–visible-NIR spectrophotometer (DUV-3700). The degradation rate of MO was calculated according to the following formula (1). Degradation rate (%)=(C0 −C)/C0 (1) Where C0 is the initial concentration of MO solution, C is the concentration after photo-degradation. The stability test of Leaf-shaped MoS2 on the degradation of MO was conducted for ten cycles. The same photo-catalyst was recovered by centrifugation at 1–2 of pH value. A separate photo-degradation experiment was conducted during each cycle. For OH radical detection, the experimental procedure is the same as the measurement of photo-catalytic activity, except for replacing MO by terephthalic acid (TA). The 5×10−4 M TA solution was catalyzed by Leaf-shaped MoS2 at different pH value, and the PL spectra were measured on a FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer at 13 of pH value. The reaction solution emits fluorescence spectra at around 425nm on the excitation of 315nm light. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphologies and structural characterizations Fig. 1a displays a typical TEM image of the Leaf-shaped MoS2 sheets synthesized by adding TEOS at a SiO2/MoS2 mole ratio of 2.5. As can be found, numerous nanosheets with an average diameter 200–300nm presented thin leaf shape. The corresponding HRTEM image is shown in Fig. 1c. It is observed that the thickness of layers are about 3–4nm with 5–7 layers in the panoramic view of HRTEM. The selected area electron diffraction pattern inserted in Fig. 1c denotes dispersion rings which suggest our prepared Leaf-shaped MoS2 sheets are almost amorphous after NaOH treatment. TEOS was hydrolyzed into the activated silicic acid (H2SiO3) at 1.0–2.0 of pH value. The H2SiO3 works as template and provides steric hindrance for the MoS2 growth. After removal of the H2SiO3 by NaOH the void spaces remained, and Leaf-shaped MoS2 sheets were observed. Therefore, the addition of TEOS plays a vital role in forming the exfoliated structure. To study the template effects of H2SiO3, we carried out the synthesis by adding different amount of TEOS. Fig. 1b is the TEM images of Flower-shaped MoS2 which is produced by adding TEOS at the SiO2/MoS2 molar ratio of 0.8. Fig. 1d is the HRTEM images corresponding to the Fig. 1b. As can be seen, Flower-shaped MoS2 yields thicker layers of MoS2 which demonstrates the higher crystalline in the final sample. This can also be substantiated by the selected area electronic diffraction (SAED) pattern as the inset figure in Fig. 1d in which resolved rings was found clearly. To sum up, when the dosage of TEOS is controlled within a low level, e.g., the SiO2/MoS2 mole ratio of 0.8, the amount of silicic acid hydrogel obtained is not enough to function as templates, so MoS2 grows into the flowers according to its growth habits [23]. With the increase of the amount of TEOS to SiO2/MoS2 molar ratio of 2.5, the growth of MoS2 is restricted by the hydrogel of silicic acid to form Leaf-shaped MoS2 exfoliated sheets, and the layers of MoS2 also become thin. Raman spectra are used to characterize the structural and chemical environment of MoS2. As reported by Lee [24] and Castellanos-Gomez et al., [25] there are two characteristic Raman bands corresponding to the band gap of in-plane E1 2g and out-of-plane A1g vibration in the vicinity of 400cm−1. Fig. 2a shows the two typical Raman peaks of the samples Flower-shaped MoS2 and Leaf-shaped MoS2 synthesized with different addition of TEOS. It is found the wavelength shifts in both E1 2g and A1g bands when we compared the two Raman peaks (shown by the dash dot lines in Fig. 2a). Compared with Flower-shaped MoS2, Leaf-shaped MoS2 exhibits blue shifts of the E1 2g vibration but red shifts of the A1g vibration. This difference could be due to the different thickness of MoS2 layers that could provide asymmetry vibration in case of elementary sheets [24,25]. For example, the nanosheets of Flower-shaped MoS2 contains more than 20 layers while those of the Leaf-shaped MoS2 are very thin, and only 5–7 layers were observed (As seen in Fig. 1). The chemical environments of both MoS2 layers are quite different, thus give different Raman modes as a result. The proposed synthesis pathway is confirmed by the XRD analysis. Both XRD profiles of Leaf-shaped MoS2 and Flower-shaped MoS2 are presented in Fig. 2b. It is obvious that the Flower-shaped MoS2 shows better resolved diffraction peaks than the Leaf-shaped MoS2. As shown by the black profile of Flower-shaped MoS2, the XRD peaks at 2θ of 7.2° and 14.4° corresponding to (001) and (002) are observed. In the counterpart of Leaf-shaped MoS2 (red curve), there is only one peak at 6.72° (<7.2°) that can be indexed to (001). The relative peaks intensity is greatly weakened, and the half-maximum width is broadened compared to the Flower-shaped MoS2. This suggests the crystallinity of Leaf-shaped MoS2 is much lower than that of Flower-shaped MoS2. The enlarged d-spacing calculated by the left-shift in 2θ (6.72°) in the Leaf-shaped MoS2 is also a reflection of expansion, and finally the disappearance denotes the complete exfoliation of the layers of MoS2. For other peaks which are marked with (hkl) in the profile, e.g., the characteristic peaks at 33.4°, 39.6°, 42.9°, 49.8°and 58.0° correspond to the crystal plane of (100), (103), (006), (105) and (110). These peaks can be ascribed to hexagonal MoS2 (JCPDS No. 77-1716). The isotherms of adsorption–desorption and BJH pore size distribution of the two MoS2 samples are shown in Fig. 3 and Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 3a, the adsorption–desorption isotherms of the Leaf-shaped MoS2 are type-IV profiles with H3-type hysteresis loop which is typical characteristics of mesoporous materials. Its hysteresis loop is found in the P/P 0 range of 0.5–1.0 in the isotherms, while that of Flower-shaped MoS2 is found in P/P 0 range of 0.9–1.0. The hysteresis loop is closely related to the pore structure. Fig. 3b shows the BJH pore size distribution profile of the two samples. We can find that the pore size of Leaf-shaped MoS2 lies in 2–4nm and 5–25nm, while the pore size of Flower-shaped MoS2 lies in 2–5nm and >15nm. After further comparative, the narrower pores (2–4nm) are easier to be formed in Leaf-shaped MoS2, while broader sized peak (>15nm) of Flower-shaped MoS2 is much more prominent than that of Leaf-shaped MoS2. Therefore the Leaf-shaped MoS2 possesses a higher specific surface area (SSA) (37.8m2/g), while the Flower-shaped MoS2 only has a SSA of 18.9m2/g. The pore volume of Leaf-shaped MoS2 is 0.216cm3/g, and it is also much higher than that of Flower-shaped MoS2 (0.140cm3/g). 3.2 Deep UV-visible-NIR spectrophotometers In order to study the optical absorbance properties of the prepared MoS2 sheets, the UV–visible-NIR diffuse reflection spectrum was tested, and the resulting spectra are displayed in Fig. 4a. As is seen from the graph, both Leaf-shaped MoS2 and Flower-shaped MoS2 present strong optical absorbance from 230nm to 1200nm, and there are two strong absorbance regions in 260–340nm (ultraviolet region) and 460–900nm (visible region) respectively. Specifically, A and B excitonic peaks arising from the K point of the Brillouin zone were observed between 580 and 700nm. But convoluted C and D excitonic peaks did not appear around 430nm. These features indicate incomplete 2H phase of the exfoliated sheets of MoS2 [14]. By comparison, the peak of visible region is much stronger than that of ultraviolet region. This implies the nanosheets of MoS2 possess high visible light absorption capability. After further comparative, the absorbance peaks intensity of Leaf-shaped MoS2 is higher markedly than that of Flower-shaped MoS2. This can be ascribed to the layer thickness of MoS2 nanosheets. Due to the layer, thickness of Leaf-shaped MoS2 is much thinner than that of Flower-shaped MoS2 (as seen in Fig. 1), its absorbance peaks are higher marked than that of Flower-shaped MoS2. Therefore, the optical absorbance of MoS2 is dependent on the layer thickness, i.e., the intensity of UV–visible-NIR absorbance increases with the thickness of MoS2 layers decreasing. 3.3 Photo-degradation The adsorption of MO on the surface of catalyst was measured by carrying out a similar experiment in the dark. We find the adsorption is so little that we cannot find the change of the concentration of MO solution, which can be due to the excellent solubility of MO in water solution of low concentration. Therefore, the degradation rate of MO is not due to its adsorption on the surface of MoS2, but photo-catalytic degradation by the exfoliated sheets of MoS2. Fig. 4b shows photo-catalytic degradation kinetic curves of MO by Leaf-shaped MoS2 and Flower-shaped MoS2 under visible light. As is shown in the figure, the photo-degradation rate of Leaf-shaped MoS2 is much higher than that of Flower-shaped MoS2 under the same condition. In general, there are two reasons for the improvement of degradation rate. For one, photo-catalytic activity correlates linearly with the number of edge sites on the MoS2 catalyst. Increasing the number of active edge sites per unit volume, photo-catalytic activity of MoS2 can be improved markedly [26–28]. Leaf-shaped MoS2 and Flower-shaped MoS2 are two kinds of MoS2 with different layer structure. Leaf-shaped MoS2 was prepared by using H2SiO3 exfoliation. It presents separated exfoliated sheets. Compared with Flower-shaped MoS2, it possesses larger specific surface area and thinner layer structure which lead to its larger number of active edge sites per unit volume. Therefore, Leaf-shaped MoS2 shows higher photo-catalytic activity. In addition, the thinner layer structure of Leaf-shaped MoS2 also leads to its higher visible light absorption capability (see Fig. 4a), which is also an important cause for its higher photo-degradation rate. Finally, we can conclude that the increasing of photo-catalytic activity for Leaf-shaped MoS2 is ascribed to the H2SiO3 exfoliation of MoS2. Fig. 5a displays the change of degradation rate of MO with the pH value by Leaf-shaped MoS2. In this section, the degradation rate is calculated according to the absorbance of MO measured at wavelengths of 464, 485 and 507nm, corresponding to the maximum absorption wavelength at pH=9, 6 and 2, respectively. As seen in Fig. 5a, MO can be degraded perfectly at 1–3 of pH value of the MO solution, and the degradation rate changes a little. However, the degradation rate decreases rapidly with the pH value increasing from 3 to 7, the degradation of MO is difficult to occur especially in the alkaline catalytic system, for example, the degradation rate of MO is only 7.8% at 9 of pH value. In order to investigate the cause of change of degradation rate with pH value, the mechanism of photo-degradation should be explored. The adsorption of MO on the surface of catalyst was measured in the dark by adjusting the pH value of the solution. The results show there is no change of the concentration of MO solution after adsorption by Leaf-shaped MoS2 which may be due to the excellent solubility of MO in aqueous solution of low concentration. Therefore, the degradation rate of MO does not depend on adsorption performance of Leaf-shaped MoS2. The excellent catalytic properties of Leaf-shaped MoS2 may play a major role in degradation of MO. Generally speaking, the catalytic mechanisms probably involve dye photo-sensitization and photo-catalytic process [29]. For a dye photosensitization process, the energy of irradiation light could stimulate the dye to form photo-induced electrons. The dye photo-sensitization process is closely related to the UV–visible absorbance of MO solution. Fig. 5b shows UV–visible absorption spectrum of MO solution at different pH value. It is observed that the change of MO structure causes blue shift of the absorbance peak with the pH increasing. The absorbance peak of MO solution at 9 of pH value is still very broad and high. However, as is seen in Fig. 5a, the degradation rate of MO at 9 of pH value is only 7.8%. Therefore, the dye photo-sensitization process can be negligible. The MO degradation may occur mainly through the semiconductor-photocatalyzed pathway. As is known, the photo-catalysts can be excited to generate electron–hole pairs directly after illumination in the photo-catalytic oxidation process. Various primary reactive species, including hydroxyl radical OH, photo-generated hole h +, superoxide radical O 2 − could be formed during the photo-catalytic degradation process [29–32]. The scavenger experiments can reveal the roles of the primary reactive species [33]. To determine OH, the terephthalic acid (TA) solution was catalyzed by Leaf-shaped MoS2 at different pH value. TA can react with OH readily to produce a highly fluorescent product, 2-Hydroxyterephthalic acid, whose PL peak intensity is directly proportional to the amount of OH radicals produced in aqueous solution. [34] (2) OH + TA → TAOH Fig. 6 shows the PL spectra at different pH value. By comparing the intensity of fluorescence signal, it was found that the amount of hydroxyl radicals reaches the largest value at the 1 or 2 of pH value. However, it decreases with the increasing of pH value and becomes very little at 9 of pH value. These results agree well with the photocatalytic activity at different pH value, indicating that OH plays a major role in MO photo-degradation in the catalytic system. In acidic or alkaline condition, the OH formed through different pathway, which is be closely related to the H+ or OH− adsorbed in the surface of catalysts [4,5]. In this catalytic system, Leaf-shaped MoS2 with ultra-thin layer structure possesses a large number of active edge sites per unit volume and free layers of sulfur atoms which easily adsorb H+, [26–28] and thereby facilitates the formation of OH. The photogenerated h + reacted with surface water to form OH, the photogenerated electrons were absorbed by oxygen on the surface of catalyst to form O 2 −. These O 2 − reacted with surface H+ again formed HO2 species which produced OH radical in subsequent steps. The radical chain mechanism of Leaf-shaped under visible light radiation can be as follows: (3) MoS 2 + hv → h + + e − (4) h + + H 2 O → H + + OH (5) e − + O 2 → O 2 - (6) O 2 − + H + → HO 2 (7) 2 HO 2 → H 2 O 2 + O 2 (8) H 2 O 2 + hv → 2 OH (9) MO dye + OH + O 2 → deg radation products A deduction can be obtained from above equation and experimental results, H+ adsorbed on the surface of MoS2 in strong acid solution may facilitate producing OH by accelerating formation of HO2 . The OH was an extremely strong, non-selective oxidant, which led to complete mineralization of MO. The effect of Leaf-shaped MoS2 dosage on degradation rate of MO was also investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 7a. As shown in the figure, when the amount of catalyst increased in the suspension, the photo-catalytic degradation rate of MO increased and reached a maximum at 0.5g/L, after which it decreased upon further loading. At a higher dose (>0.5g/L), the opaqueness of the photo-catalyst reduced the transparency of the solution, produced light scattering and light reflection as a result of an increase in the turbidity of the suspension, and consequently reduced the photo-catalytic activity.[1] Thus, 0.5g/L was determined to be the optimum catalyst dose for the experimental studies. The effect of initial concentration of MO solution on degradation rate was also investigated. Fig. 7b shows photo-catalytic degradation kinetic curves of MO solution of different initial concentration. As can be seen from the figure, the degradation rate of MO decreased with the increasing of the initial concentration at the same condition. This phenomenon can be explained by the following reasons. One is that, at the higher MO concentration, light transmittance of the dye solution is reduced to some extent, which in turn causes fewer incident photons to reach the catalyst surface, resulting in a decrease of degradation rate [35]. Another reason is that, under the same conditions, the MO solution of the higher concentration must be degraded for the longer time. For practical applications, it is significant to determine the stabilities of catalysts under visible light irradiation. Therefore, the used catalyst was collected after each run, dried and reused under the same experimental conditions. Fig. 8 shows the results of 10 successive MO degradation runs using Leaf-shaped MoS2. As can be seen, the Leaf-shaped MoS2 can be reused ten times with little change of degradation rate, indicating that they are stable under visible-light irradiation. 4 Conclusions MoS2 nanosheets were prepared by H2SiO3 exfoliation. The appropriate dosage of hydrogel of silicic acid is the determining factor in preparing homogeneous exfoliated sheets of MoS2. The prepared MoS2 nanosheets possess a high specific surface area of 37.8m2/g, and present excellent UV–visible-NIR absorbance properties, and the absorption peaks of visible region are much higher than that of ultraviolet region. Therefore, they can be used as excellent catalysts for visible-light-driven degradation of MO. The photo-degradation optimized parameters of MO by MoS2 nanosheets are as follows, pH=2, the initial concentration: 50mg/L, reaction time: 70min, dosage of catalyst: 0.5g/L. coredata.dc:description: MoS2 nanosheets were for the first time prepared by H2SiO3 exfoliation, i.e., the precursors ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and thiourea) were embedded inside the hydrogel of H2SiO3 which provides steric hindrance for MoS2 growth. After removal of H2SiO3, MoS2 nanosheets were obtained. The appropriate dosage of hydrogel of silicic acid is the determining factor in preparing homogeneous nanosheets of MoS2. The prepared MoS2 nanosheets possess a high specific surface area of 37.8m2/g, and present excellent UV–visible-NIR absorbance properties, and the absorption peaks of visible region are much higher than that of ultraviolet region. Therefore, they can be used as excellent catalysts for visible-light-driven degradation of methyl orange (MO). The effect of photo-degradation parameters of MO including pH value, dosage of catalyst and initial concentration was studied. The strongly acidic solution of MO facilitates producing free radicals of OH in this catalytic system. The MoS2 nanosheets can be reused 10 times with little change of degradation rate, indicating that they are stable under visible-light irradiation.
coredata.dc:title: Photo-catalytic degradation of methyl orange under visible light by MoS2 nanosheets produced by H2SiO3 exfoliation
